title: Bounded Rationality
summary: Herbert Simon's core insight: humans don't optimize, they satisfice. We decide with incomplete information, finite time, and limited cognition. This isn't a flaw — it's the operating condition. Two people with identical values will reach different conclusions simply because they're working from different slices of reality. Most institutional design fails because it assumes rational actors with full information. Stop asking "why don't people just..." and start designing for how people actually think.

title: No Fundamental Value Differences
summary: Most apparent value clashes aren't deep disagreements — they're artefacts of bounded rationality, polysemy (the same words meaning different things to different people), impatience to bridge inferential gaps, and two-level games where claiming incommensurable values is strategically useful for in-group cohesion. Strip away the noise and people want remarkably similar things: safety, dignity, agency, belonging. This applies at every scale — not just between nations, but between departments, subcultures, generations, any boundary where in-group and out-group form.

title: The Need for Economic Growth
summary: Growth isn't greed — it's the prerequisite for everything else. Health systems, climate adaptation, scientific research, safety nets, space exploration — all funded by surplus, and surplus requires growth. Global GDP needs to roughly 10x before redistribution alone can meaningfully close gaps; until then, making the pie bigger isn't optional, it's arithmetic. A world that stops growing turns every allocation into a zero-sum fight, and zero-sum games breed conflict. The question is how to grow sustainably, inclusively, and toward things that actually matter.

title: Good Faith & Hyperstitioning Abundance
summary: We need to simultaneously pursue technological solutions and modify culture toward what actually matters — walking a tightrope between both. Hyperstition is the key mechanism: act as if a better world is already emerging, and the acting helps make it real. But this only works if grounded in good faith — assuming others share the goal even when their methods differ. Without good faith you get cynicism; without cultural realignment you get tech solutionism; without technology you get wishful thinking. The trick is holding all three at once.

title: Limits to Growth Rate & Maximum Scale
summary: Every entity — company, community, institution, movement — has a natural growth rate it can sustain without losing coherence. Grow too fast and culture breaks, quality drops, trust erodes. There's also a maximum scale beyond which coordination costs exceed the value of coordination. This is why the right answer is often many small things, not one big thing. Networks over monoliths.

title: Coordination Is the Bottleneck
summary: Most problems that look like knowledge problems or resource problems are actually coordination problems. We often know what to do. We frequently have what we need. What's missing is the ability to get enough people aligned, trusting, and acting in concert. This is true at every scale: relationships, teams, organizations, nations, civilization.

title: Comfort Reduces Agency
summary: The more comfortable you are, the less likely you are to change anything — including things that desperately need changing. Comfort is an anaesthetic for ambition, curiosity, and moral urgency. This doesn't mean seek suffering. It means be suspicious of complacency, especially your own.

title: Everything Should Be Thinkable
summary: No idea should be off-limits for consideration. The moment you declare a thought unthinkable, you lose the ability to reason about it — and reasoning about hard things is exactly how you avoid the worst outcomes. This is not the same as saying everything should be done. Thinking is not endorsing. The strongest taboos should be on actions, not thoughts.

title: The Uncanny Valley of Improvement
summary: To get from a local optimum to a better one, things will temporarily get worse. The art is being fine with this. Moving from hare hunting (everyone fends for themselves, safe but mediocre) to stag hunting (coordinated trust, high payoff) means tolerating failed stag hunts along the way — coordination skills and infrastructure are a fail-forward exercise. Depending on the scale of change, the discomfort might last a good while. But with the right entourage and a shared compass, you can survive the valley.
